fields.name: Title
fields.description: Full title of the study as stated in the paper
fields.value: Comparing ChatGPT-4 and Human Translation of an Outcome Questionnaire: A Randomized, Double-Blinded Non-inferiority Study
fields.evidence_quote: Comparing ChatGPT-4 and Human Translation of an Outcome Questionnaire: A Randomized, Double-Blinded Non-inferiority Study

fields.name: Author(s)
fields.description: List of all authors involved in the paper, in order of appearance
fields.value: Christopher B Sørensen, Anders Gram-Hanssen, Jacob Rosenberg, Jason J Baker
fields.evidence_quote: Christopher B Sørensen, Anders Gram-Hanssen, Jacob Rosenberg, Jason J Baker

fields.name: Patient Co-authors
fields.description: Were any co-authors identified as patients or caregivers?
fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.name: Journal
fields.description: Name of the journal where the study was published
fields.evidence_quote: Cureus

fields.name: Publication Stage
fields.description: Indicate if the paper is peer-reviewed, a preprint, or another stage
fields.evidence_quote: Accepted 2025 Apr 17; Collection date 2025 Apr.

fields.name: Publication Date
fields.description: Official date the paper was published

fields.name: Field of Study
fields.description: Disciplinary or clinical field, such as primary care, oncology, or public health
fields.evidence_quote: Surgery, Herlev Hospital, Herlev, DNK

fields.name: Country
fields.description: Country or countries where the study was conducted or primarily situated
fields.evidence_quote: DNK

fields.name: Type of Article
fields.description: Classify the article: original research, protocol, review, commentary, etc.
fields.evidence_quote: This study aimed to investigate whether ChatGPT-4 could replace traditional forward-backward translation by humans when translating a questionnaire into another language through a non-inferiority design.

fields.name: Aim of Study
fields.description: State the main purpose or objective of the study as described by the authors
fields.value: To investigate whether ChatGPT-4 could replace traditional forward-backward translation by humans when translating a medical outcome questionnaire from English to Danish in a non-inferiority design.
fields.evidence_quote: This study aimed to investigate whether ChatGPT-4 could replace traditional forward-backward translation by humans when translating a medical outcome questionnaire from English to Danish in a non-inferiority design.

fields.name: Key Findings
fields.description: Summarize the main results or conclusions of the study
fields.value: ChatGPT-4 may serve as a suitable substitute for traditional forward-backward translation when translating an outcome questionnaire, provided that the ChatGPT-4 translation is subjected to human quality control and is pretested through face validation before clinical use.
fields.evidence_quote: ChatGPT-4 may serve as a suitable substitute for traditional forward-backward translation when translating an outcome questionnaire, provided that the ChatGPT-4 translation is subjected to human quality control and is pretested through face validation before clinical use.

fields.name: Patient/Public Engagement (Y/N)
fields.description: Does the study report any involvement of patients or the public? This includes participation, feedback, consultation, or co-design.
fields.evidence_quote: For this study, the questionnaire was translated from English to Danish twice, once using ChatGPT-4 and once by human translators [16]. A comparison of the translations was made before and after the face validation process, which involved a series of participant interviews aimed at improving the questionnaires and providing evidence for their face validity.

fields.name: Type of Engagement (Montreal Model continuum)
fields.description: Categorize engagement based on the Montreal Model: Information, Consultation, Collaboration, or Partnership.
fields.evidence_quote: A comparison of the translations was made before and after the face validation process, which involved a series of participant interviews aimed at improving the questionnaires and providing evidence for their face validity.

fields.name: Evaluation of Impact (Y/N)
fields.description: Did the study evaluate or measure the effect of patient/public engagement?
fields.evidence_quote: The primary objective was to compare the two translated questionnaires after face validation by assessing the readability, comprehension, usage of appropriate language, and the participants’ overall opinions.

fields.name: Type of Evaluation
fields.description: What type of method or framework was used to evaluate the impact of engagement (e.g., metrics, qualitative feedback, evaluation framework)?
fields.evidence_quote: For this assessment, participants answered four questions using a Likert scale from 1 to 5.

fields.name: Impact of Engagement
fields.description: Describe any outcomes or changes attributed to patient/public engagement (e.g., design changes, improved recruitment, insights).
fields.evidence_quote: After face validation, there were no significant differences regarding readability, comprehension, appropriate use of language, and overall opinion of the questionnaire

fields.name: Participatory Process
fields.description: Did the study include a participatory design process such as workshops, co-design, or stakeholder sessions?
fields.evidence_quote: A comparison of the translations was made before and after the face validation process, which involved a series of participant interviews aimed at improving the questionnaires and providing evidence for their face validity.

fields.name: Continuous Evaluation Cycles
fields.description: Was engagement conducted iteratively or cyclically, with feedback loops or repeated interaction?
fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.evidence_quote: N/A

fields.name: Assess Impact
fields.description: Did the study measure outcomes or success metrics related specifically to engagement efforts?
fields.evidence_quote: The primary objective was to compare the two translated questionnaires after face validation by assessing the readability, comprehension, usage of appropriate language, and the participants’ overall opinions.

fields.name: Information
fields.description: Was information provided to patients/public about the study, without involving them in decision-making?

fields.name: Consultation

fields.evidence_quote: A comparison of the translations was made before and after the face validation process, which involved a series of participant interviews aimed at improving the questionnaires and providing evidence for their face validity.

fields.name: Collaboration
